resps:
The present invention relates to a digital-to-analog converter which comprises a digital filter for reducing noise of a digital signal in a digital-to-analog converter which converts a digital signal to an analog signal.
In recent years, there are increasing needs for converting analog signals such as speech signals to a digital signal which can be handled by a computer or the like and then performing various digital processes. An acoustic digitalization is a typical example, and there are increasing needs for various types of acoustic equipment such as a CD multi-media player, an electronic still camera and an equalizer.
An electret condenser microphone (ECM) is widely used as a microphone for general speech sound in which dynamic properties of speech sound are relatively important. As the performance of equipment in which the electret condenser microphone unit is built-in is increasingly required, various types of electret condenser microphones have been developed so far.
For example, in a digital microphone system for converting a voice signal to an electric signal and then storing it in a magnetic disk unit or the like, a condenser microphone unit is required to have a sound pressure characteristic which has an S/N ratio as high as 50dB or thereabouts in which distortion is minimized and the peak level is not remarkably high. As a condenser microphone unit for this purpose, an integrated type condenser microphone unit formed by combining and integrating a diaphragm, a spacer and a fixed capacitor is known.
It is a common practice that, in an integrated type condenser microphone unit, a high frequency signal which is obtained by high-pass-filtering an output signal of the condenser microphone unit at a certain frequency is used as a signal to control a driving pulse width of a push-pull type speaker and thus improve the sound pressure characteristic.
FIG. 15 shows a conventional digital microphone system 500 comprising an electric circuit section 501 and an electret condenser microphone unit 502.
As shown in FIG. 15, the electric circuit section 501 comprises a high-pass filter circuit 516 comprising passive parts having resistor R1 and capacitor C1 and a capacitor C2, outputting a high frequency signal to a comparator 518. The voltage of capacitor C2 is compared by the comparator 518 with a reference voltage Vref to control timing at which the output of comparator 518 changes and thus generate control pulse Cp for controlling a push-pull type speaker. This pulse Cp is amplified by an amplifier 515 and then applied to a push-pull type speaker 513 of the electret condenser microphone unit 502.
The digital microphone system 500 is such that an output signal obtained by the electret condenser microphone unit 502 is A/D converted by an A/D converter 514 and thus a digital signal is obtained. The digital signal is subjected to various digital processes by a digital unit 503. Digital microphone system 500 as mentioned above is disclosed in, for example, Japanese Laid-Open Patent Application No. 62-185853 (e.g., page 2, FIG. 1).
FIG. 16 shows a block diagram of a conventional voice recognition system 601.
The voice recognition system 601 comprises an electret condenser microphone unit 602, an amplitude detecting/high-pass-filtering section 604, a waveform segmenting section 606 and a feature amount extracting section 608. The voice input into the voice recognition system 601 is converted to a digital signal by the electret condenser microphone unit 602 and thus a digital signal D1 is obtained.
A voice signal is input into the amplitude detecting/high-pass-filtering section 604. A high frequency signal component is thus extracted and then is amplified by amplifier 605 and high-pass-filtered. The output of amplifier 605 is compared with a reference voltage Vref in an amplifier 612 by an amplifier 609. Amplifier 609 changes a timing at which an output thereof changes in response to a frequency of a high frequency signal input via a capacitor 607. The output of amplifier 609 is also input into the waveform segmenting section 606. The amplitudes of the output of amplifier 609 at timing at which the output changes are waveform segmented by the waveform segmenting section 606. A feature amount signal D2 being a representative signal of an input speech voice is obtained by executing predetermined processes such as calculation processing and integration processing on each amplitude of the divided pieces of waveform.
Feature amount signal D2 is input into the feature amount extracting section 608. The feature amount signal D2 is input into a data comparison unit 614 connected to the outside whereby it is compared with a feature amount of an input voice signal on the outside. The compared result is compared by a data judgement unit 612 with a feature amount which has been recognized as a speech voice (hereinbelow, simply "recognized feature amount") beforehand and if they are coincident, it is judged that a voice which is input into the voice recognition system 601 is the input voice signal and the result of judgment is output as "voice" from a judgement unit 613.
The voice recognition system 601 is disclosed in, for example, Japanese Laid-Open Patent Application No. 7-294470 (e.g., FIG. 5).
As is described above, in the digital microphone system 500, the output of the electret condenser microphone unit 502 is A/D converted and thus a digital signal D1 is obtained. Digital signal D1 is then subject to various digital processes (e.g., filtering and voice recognition). It is, therefore, desirable that a noise component is not included in the digital signal D1 obtained in this case and noise is as little as possible in order to obtain a digital signal D1 which is as much as possible as a digital signal D1 for digital processing of a speech signal.
It is, therefore, an object of the present invention to provide a method or system for generating an analog signal from a digital signal with reduced noise, a digital-to-analog converter (D/A converter) according to the present invention, a D/A converter circuit of the present invention and a D/A converter for converting to an analog signal in order to obtain a digital signal D1 with reduced noise.

resps:
Aminophylline in the treatment of neonatal apneas.
The authors report an open study in premature infants under 36 weeks of gestation, weighing under 3,000 g, and with apneas. 15 infants were treated with aminophylline (0.2 mg/kg twice a day). There were a total of 8,567 apneas (84.18 per cent) and 22 (1.9%) bradycardias. In the period which preceded the beginning of treatment, the mean frequency was 72.7 apneas per day and 1.7 bradycardias per day; the frequency in the following period was 60 apneas per day and 10.7 bradycardias per day. Mean age at study start was 9.7 weeks; weight 1,897 g, cephalic perimeter 27.3 cm. Total of 9,547 apneas and 33 bradycardias were observed after treatment. There was an average of 30 apneas per day and one bradycardia per day. The frequency of apneas observed was significantly lower than that prior to the beginning of treatment (p less than 0.001). These preliminary and promising results justify a randomized and controlled study of the use of aminophylline in the treatment of apneas of newborn infants.

resps:
1. Technical Field
The present invention relates generally to methods and apparatus for improving the quality of digital images received over a communications network.
2. Description of Related Art
A number of systems exist for transmitting and viewing digital images over a communications network. Such systems may be implemented through, for example, image files, image web pages, photo-service networks, instant messaging, e-mail, and photo e-mail systems, to name a few. Each of these systems enables the display and transmission of digital images stored on one or more servers within a network.
Unfortunately, systems of this type are typically prone to numerous undesirable effects. For example, these types of networks are susceptible to image quality degradation including compression artifacts, “banding” artifacts, and “softening”, each of which may be experienced in varying degrees depending on the type of network and the bandwidth available to a particular user. Compression artifacts generally appear as an increase in the blurriness or ringing of edges of high frequency images. Banding artifacts generally appear as a band of darker or lighter areas (e.g. “banding blacks”) and softening generally appears as a reduction in the high frequency range of an image, resulting in a low signal-to-noise ratio.
Therefore, there is a need for an improved system and method for transmitting and viewing digital images that reduces the effects of image quality degradation.

resps:
Aminophylline in the treatment of neonatal apneas.
The authors report an open study in premature infants under 36 weeks of gestation, weighing under 3,000 g, and with apneas. 15 infants were treated with aminophylline (0.2 mg/kg twice a day). There were a total of 8,567 apneas (84.18 per cent) and 22 (1.9%) bradycardias. In the period which preceded the beginning of treatment, the mean frequency was 72.7 apneas per day and 1.7 bradycardias per day; the frequency in the following period was 60 apneas per day and 10.7 bradycardias per day. Mean age at study start was 9.7 weeks; weight 1,897 g, cephalic perimeter 27.3 cm. Total of 9,547 apneas and 33 bradycardias were observed after treatment. There was an average of 30 apneas per day and one bradycardia per day. The frequency of apneas observed was significantly lower than that prior to the beginning of treatment (p less than 0.001). These preliminary and promising results justify a randomized and controlled study of the use of aminophylline in the treatment of apneas of newborn infants.

resps:
1. Technical Field
The present invention relates generally to methods and apparatus for improving the quality of digital images received over a communications network.
2. Description of Related Art
A number of systems exist for transmitting and viewing digital images over a communications network. Such systems may be implemented through, for example, image files, image web pages, photo-service networks, instant messaging, e-mail, and photo e-mail systems, to name a few. Each of these systems enables the display and transmission of digital images stored on one or more servers within a network.
Unfortunately, systems of this type are typically prone to numerous undesirable effects. For example, these types of networks are susceptible to image quality degradation including compression artifacts, “banding” artifacts, and “softening”, each of which may be experienced in varying degrees depending on the type of network and the bandwidth available to a particular user. Compression artifacts generally appear as an increase in the blurriness or ringing of edges of high frequency images. Banding artifacts generally appear as a band of darker or lighter areas (e.g. “banding blacks”) and softening generally appears as a reduction in the high frequency range of an image, resulting in a low signal-to-noise ratio.
Therefore, there is a need for an improved system and method for transmitting and viewing digital images that reduces the effects of image quality degradation.

resps:
Aminophylline in the treatment of neonatal apneas.
The authors report an open study in premature infants under 36 weeks of gestation, weighing under 3,000 g, and with apneas. 15 infants were treated with aminophylline (0.2 mg/kg twice a day). There were a total of 8,567 apneas (84.18 per cent) and 22 (1.9%) bradycardias. In the period which preceded the beginning of treatment, the mean frequency was 72.7 apneas per day and 1.7 bradycardias per day; the frequency in the following period was 60 apneas per day and 10.7 bradycardias per day. Mean age at study start was 9.7 weeks; weight 1,897 g, cephalic perimeter 27.3 cm. Total of 9,547 apneas and 33 bradycardias were observed after treatment. There was an average of 30 apneas per day and one bradycardia per day. The frequency of apneas observed was significantly lower than that prior to the beginning of treatment (p less than 0.001). These preliminary and promising results justify a randomized and controlled study of the use of aminophylline in the treatment of apneas of newborn infants.

resps:
1. Technical Field
The present invention relates generally to methods and apparatus for improving the quality of digital images received over a communications network.
2. Description of Related Art
A number of systems exist for transmitting and viewing digital images over a communications network. Such systems may be implemented through, for example, image files, image web pages, photo-service networks, instant messaging, e-mail, and photo e-mail systems, to name a few. Each of these systems enables the display and transmission of digital images stored on one or more servers within a network.
Unfortunately, systems of this type are typically prone to numerous undesirable effects. For example, these types of networks are susceptible to image quality degradation including compression artifacts, “banding” artifacts, and “softening”, each of which may be experienced in varying degrees depending on the type of network and the bandwidth available to a particular user. Compression artifacts generally appear as an increase in the blurriness or ringing of edges of high frequency images. Banding artifacts generally appear as a band of darker or lighter areas (e.g. “banding blacks”) and softening generally appears as a reduction in the high frequency range of an image, resulting in a low signal-to-noise ratio.
Therefore, there is a need for an improved system and method for transmitting and viewing digital images that reduces the effects of image quality degradation.

It is a common practice that, in an integrated type condenser microphone unit, a high frequency signal which is obtained by high-pass-filtering an output signal of the condenser microphone unit at a certain frequency is used as a signal to control a driving pulse width of a push-pull type speaker and thus improve the sound pressure characteristic.
FIG. 15 shows a conventional digital microphone system 500 comprising an electric circuit section 501 and an electret condenser microphone unit 502.
As shown in FIG. 15, the electric circuit section 501 comprises a high-pass filter circuit 516 comprising passive parts having resistor R1 and capacitor C1 and a capacitor C2, outputting a high frequency signal to a comparator 518. The voltage of capacitor C2 is compared by the comparator 518 with a reference voltage Vref to control timing at which the output of comparator 518 changes and thus generate control pulse Cp for controlling a push-pull type speaker. This pulse Cp is amplified by an amplifier 515 and then applied to a push-pull type speaker 513 of the electret condenser microphone unit 502.
The digital microphone system 500 is such that an output signal obtained by the electret condenser microphone unit 502 is A/D converted by an A/D converter 514 and thus a digital signal is obtained. The digital signal is subjected to various digital processes by a digital unit 503. Digital microphone system 500 as mentioned above is disclosed in, for example, Japanese Laid-Open Patent Application No. 62-185853 (e.g., page 2, FIG. 1).
FIG. 16 shows a block diagram of a conventional voice recognition system 601.
The voice recognition system 601 comprises an electret condenser microphone unit 602, an amplitude detecting/high-pass-filtering section 604, a waveform segmenting section 606 and a feature amount extracting section 608. The voice input into the voice recognition system 601 is converted to a digital signal by the electret condenser microphone unit 602 and thus a digital signal D1 is obtained.
A voice signal is input into the amplitude detecting/high-pass-filtering section 604. A high frequency signal component is thus extracted and then is amplified by amplifier 605 and high-pass-filtered. The output of amplifier 605 is compared with a reference voltage Vref in an amplifier 612 by an amplifier 609. Amplifier 609 changes a timing at which an output thereof changes in response to a frequency of a high frequency signal input via a capacitor 607. The output of amplifier 609 is also input into the waveform segmenting section 606. The amplitudes of the output of amplifier 609 at timing at which the output changes are waveform segmented by the waveform segmenting section 606. A feature amount signal D2 being a representative signal of an input speech voice is obtained by executing predetermined processes such as calculation processing and integration processing on each amplitude of the divided pieces of waveform.
Feature amount signal D2 is input into the feature amount extracting section 608. The feature amount signal D2 is input into a data comparison unit 614 connected to the outside whereby it is compared with a feature amount of an input voice signal on the outside. The compared result is compared by a data judgement unit 612 with a feature amount which has been recognized as a speech voice (hereinbelow, simply "recognized feature amount") beforehand and if they are coincident, it is judged that a voice which is input into the voice recognition system 601 is the input voice signal and the result of judgment is output as "voice" from a judgement unit 613.
The voice recognition system 601 is disclosed in, for example, Japanese Laid-Open Patent Application No. 7-294470 (e.g., FIG. 5).
As is described above, in the digital microphone system 500, the output of the electret condenser microphone unit 502 is A/D converted and thus a digital signal D1 is obtained. Digital signal D1 is then subject to various digital processes (e.g., filtering and voice recognition). It is, therefore, desirable that a noise component is not included in the digital signal D1 obtained in this case and noise is as little as possible in order to obtain a digital signal D1 which is as much as possible as a digital signal D1 for digital processing of a speech signal.
It is, therefore, an object of the present invention to provide a method or system for generating an analog signal from a digital signal with reduced noise, a digital-to-analog converter (D/A converter) according to the present invention, a D/A converter circuit of the present invention and a D/A converter for converting to an analog signal in order to obtain a digital signal D1 with reduced noise.

resps:
Aminophylline in the treatment of neonatal apneas.
The authors report an open study in premature infants under 36 weeks of gestation, weighing under 3,000 g, and with apneas. 15 infants were treated with aminophylline (0.2 mg/kg twice a day). There were a total of 8,567 apneas (84.18 per cent) and 22 (1.9%) bradycardias. In the period which preceded the beginning of treatment, the mean frequency was 72.7 apneas per day and 1.7 bradycardias per day; the frequency in the following period was 60 apneas per day and 10.7 bradycardias per day. Mean age at study start was 9.7 weeks; weight 1,897 g, cephalic perimeter 27.3 cm. Total of 9,547 apneas and 33 bradycardias were observed after treatment. There was an average of 30 apneas per day and one bradycardia per day. The frequency of apneas observed was significantly lower than that prior to the beginning of treatment (p less than 0.001). These preliminary and promising results justify a randomized and controlled study of the use of aminophylline in the treatment of apneas of newborn infants.

resps:
1. Technical Field
The present invention relates generally to methods and apparatus for improving the quality of digital images received over a communications network.
2. Description of Related Art
A number of systems exist for transmitting and viewing digital images over a communications network. Such systems may be implemented through, for example, image files, image web pages, photo-service networks, instant messaging, e-mail, and photo e-mail systems, to name a few. Each of these systems enables the display and transmission of digital images stored on one or more servers within a network.
Unfortunately, systems of this type are typically prone to numerous undesirable effects. For example, these types of networks are susceptible to image quality degradation including compression artifacts, “banding” artifacts, and “softening”, each of which may be experienced in varying degrees depending on the type of network and the bandwidth available to a particular user. Compression artifacts generally appear as an increase in the blurriness or ringing of edges of high frequency images. Banding artifacts generally appear as a band of darker or lighter areas (e.g. “banding blacks”) and softening generally appears as a reduction in the high frequency range of an image, resulting in a low signal-to-noise ratio.
Therefore, there is a need for an improved system and method for transmitting and viewing digital images that reduces the effects of image quality degradation.
